feed.title: The Register
feed.subtitle: Biting the hand that feeds IT — sci/tech news and views for the world

entry.title: Wealthy London NIMBYs grit teeth, welcome 'ugly' fibre cabinets
entry.summary:
Six foot high boxes-o-infrastructure crush opposition

BT has convinced residents of Kensington and Chelsea that they can live with "ugly" fibre optic cabling cabinets on their streets. The move comes after the Royal Borough rejected 96 of the installation proposals submitted by the national telco in May last year.…

entry.title: India’s outsourcers battle for customers in a cloudy universe
entry.summary:
Still on top but heeeere comes China ...

Analysis  The rumblings started in the late 1990s. Indian services companies were getting into outsourcing. Almost before the news broke, deals followed. Before long, India was a destination for all manner of serious jobs and a byword for getting things done well and at a price western nations struggled to match.…

entry.title: Want faster fibre? Get rid of the glass

entry.title: Spanish Linux group files antitrust complaint against Microsoft

entry.title: Tibetan and Uyghur activists targeted with Android malware
entry.summary:
Hmm ... who'd want to do that?

Researchers at Kaspersky Lab are reporting that Tibetan activists are being hit by a highly targeted form of Android malware that seeks to record their contacts, call logs, SMS messages, geolocation, and phone data.…

entry.title: Swedish linguists nix new word after row with Google
entry.summary:
Online ad giant said 'nej!' to 'ogooglebar'

The Swedish Language Council, a semi-official body aimed at regulating and advancing the Swedish language, has withdrawn a word from its annual list of neologisms for the first time in its history. Why? Pressure from Google.…

entry.title: Roomba dust-bust bot bods one step closer to ROBOBUTLERS
entry.summary:

Getting computers to recognise generic objects is a hugely difficult task that’s complicated by variations of the same object (club chairs vs. office chairs vs. folding chairs) and by other objects in the computer’s field of view that can confuse the machine.…

entry.title: Whoops! Tiny bug in NetBSD 6.0 code ruins SSH crypto keys
entry.summary:
'Random numbers are too important to be left to chance'

The brains behind NetBSD have warned a bug in the open-source OS creates weak cryptographic keys that can be cracked by attackers. Users attempting to secure sensitive communications, such as SSH terminal connections, using the dodgy keys could be easily snooped on and decrypted.…

entry.title: Join us now for all the storage whispers: Heard about the XtremIO buy?
